title: Allow webviews to provide a suggested chat context

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

body: For example: When a PR webview is one of the visible editors, I want `#My PR` title to show as context, then when the user chooses to include that as context, the extension chooses what it provides as part of the context (PR title, description, comments, etc.)

body: Codebase search limits results to files it has access to. Running codesearch against the whole repo would be preferrable as it can bring in related code, types and dependencies.

title: Save & switch "Working Sets" of open files (tab groups) per workspace

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-editors
labels.description: Managing of editor widgets in workbench window

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
When working on multiple tasks in the same workspace, I often keep several files open across folders. If I need to switch to another task, I either leave all tabs open (cluttered UI) or close them and manually reopen later (time-consuming and error-prone).

It would be great a built-in way to save the current set of open files (including split layout, pinned tabs, and active file) under a name (e.g., "Feature A"), close them, and later restore that exact set with one action (e.g., "Switch to Feature B" → opens files for B, closes A).

title: Take ownership of terminal-links, terminal-find, terminal-layout, terminal-sticky-scroll, terminal-local-echo, terminal-external
Feature Request: Highlight Invisible Comments in Code Editor (Official Support with Tooltip & Markdown)

labels.name: *extension-candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as good extension implementation

body:
First of all, I apologize for this text being written with AI; I don’t speak English very well yet.

I don’t have experience developing VS Code extensions, so I tried a quick solution with the help of AI, creating this extension for testing purposes [Invisible Comments](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=natn4y.invisible-comments).


## Description:
I would like to request an official VS Code feature that allows invisible/hidden comments to be highlighted in the editor, with optional visual highlighting (can be toggled on or off). with support for tooltips and Markdown formatting, similar to what my extension [Invisible Comments](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=natn4y.invisible-comments) provides.

## Problem Statement:
Currently, VS Code does not support invisible comments natively. While extensions can provide this functionality, they have limitations in terms of performance, integration with other features, and consistency across themes and languages. An official implementation would make it more robust and widely usable.

## Proposed Solution:

Add an editor option to mark comments as "invisible" but optionally highlight them visually.

Enable tooltips: hovering over the invisible comment shows the comment content.

Support Markdown formatting inside the comment for better readability.

Allow customization of highlight style (background, underline, or color).

Support all languages and integrate with VS Code features like folding, find, and syntax highlighting.

Ensure compatibility with extensions and themes.

Persist comments in files, e.g., .comments folder at the project root, following the same folder structure as the source code.

When source files are moved, deleted, renamed, or lines are modified, automatically update the corresponding .comments entries to reflect these changes.

Keep the .comments files in sync to ensure comments remain accurate and aligned with the source code.

Repository:  https://github.com/natn4y/vs_code_invisible-comments-extension

## Benefits:

Provides a native, reliable solution for invisible comments with rich content.

Improves code readability and collaboration without relying on third-party extensions.

Enhances communication within code by allowing formatted notes, links, or instructions in tooltips.

Ensures persistent, project-wide storage of comments, safely tracking changes to source files.

Additional Context:

Inspired by my extension [Invisible Comments](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=natn4y.invisible-comments), which works well but has limitations.

title: Disable `get_task_output` and `run_task` tools when no tasks are available in workspace
body:
The `get_task_output` tool was always available in the chat interface, even when no tasks were defined in the workspace. This could confuse users who might try to use a tool that won't work since there are no tasks to get output from.

## Changes

This PR adds conditional availability to the `get_task_output` tool by:

1. **Adding a new context key** `TasksAvailableContext` that tracks whether any tasks are available in the workspace
2. **Updating the task service** to automatically maintain this context key when workspace tasks are loaded or changed
3. **Adding a `when` condition** to the tool definition so it only appears when tasks exist

## Implementation Details

The solution leverages VS Code's existing context key system that's already used throughout the codebase for conditional UI availability. The context key is updated whenever workspace tasks are computed, checking for:
- Tasks defined in `tasks.json` files
- Tasks provided by extensions
- Tasks across all workspace folders

## Example

**Before:** The get_task_output tool was always visible in chat, leading to confusing "Task not found" errors when used in workspaces without tasks.

**After:** The tool only appears when there are actually tasks available to get output from, providing a cleaner user experience.

Fixes #261676.

title: Make yolo mode more obvious and harder to use

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

body:
I see a bunch of people using yolo mode when they may not realize the risks associated with it. We mention the risks in the settings but it's still too easy to enable. I propose we:

- Show a modal that must be accepted when the setting is changed
- Show a persistent and loud banner in chat views when global auto approve is on
- Change the name to be more obvious and clear that it's not a requirement to use terminal auto approve

title: Error using "Open with", portable instalation
Use ConfigureToolsAction for MCP tools display with server filtering
body:
The MCP tools count display in mcp.json files was showing as non-clickable text (e.g., "2 tools"), making it difficult for users to discover what tools are available from MCP servers and their capabilities.

This PR implements a clickable interface that integrates with the existing VS Code tools picker infrastructure:

**Before:** 
- Tools count showed as static text with empty command ID
- No way to see tool details without external inspection

**After:**
- Tools count is now clickable 
- Opens the standard ConfigureToolsAction tool picker with:
  - Pre-filtered to show the specific MCP server
  - MCP server section expanded while others are collapsed
  - Built-in search and filtering capabilities
  - Consistent UI with existing tool management workflows

**Implementation:**
- Extended `showToolsPicker` function to accept an optional filter parameter
- Added filtering logic to expand matching MCP servers and collapse others
- Modified `ConfigureToolsAction` to extract filter from command arguments  
- Updated code lens in `mcpLanguageFeatures.ts` to use `ConfigureToolsAction.ID` with server name filter
- Removed custom `McpShowToolsForServerCommand` in favor of existing infrastructure

The implementation follows existing VS Code patterns and integrates seamlessly with the standard tool picker, providing a consistent user experience while enabling focused discovery of MCP server capabilities.

Fixes #261578.

title: Regression: tasks.json C++ build with cl.exe fails when arguments are provided

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version:  see below
- OS Version:  see below


Description:
After a recent update, VSCode seems to have introduced a bug that breaks C++ development on Windows when using cl.exe via tasks.json. Tasks that previously worked no longer execute correctly if the command includes arguments.

Steps to Reproduce:

Configure tasks.json as follows:
``` json
{
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "windows": {
        "options": {
            "shell": {
                "executable": "C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft Visual Studio\\2022\\Community\\VC\\Auxiliary\\Build\\vcvars64.bat",
                "args": [
                    "&&"
                ]
            }
        }
    },
    "tasks": [
        {
            "label": "build",
            "type": "shell",
            "command": "cl.exe",
            "args": [
                "main.cpp"
            ],
            "group": "build"
        }
    ]
}
```

Run the build task.

Expected Behavior:
cl.exe compiles main.cpp as it did prior to this regression.

Actual Behavior:
The terminal outputs:

```
Executing task in folder TaskBugReport: cl.exe main.cpp 

**********************************************************************
** Visual Studio 2022 Developer Command Prompt v17.14.5
** Copyright (c) 2025 Microsoft Corporation
**********************************************************************
[vcvarsall.bat] Environment initialized for: 'x64'
'"cl.exe main.cpp"' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.
```


The task works correctly if you run cl.exe without arguments, but fails as soon as any argument is added.

Additional Information / Attempts:

Tried configuring terminal.integrated.automationProfile.windows to run vcvars64.bat with /k and &&, but cl.exe is not found, indicating that the task is not executed in the correct environment.

This appears to be a regression compared to previous VSCode behavior, where tasks could run cl.exe with arguments in a shell initialized via vcvars64.bat.

Environment:
Version: 1.103.1 (user setup)
Commit: 360a4e4fd251bfce169a4ddf857c7d25d1ad40da
Date: 2025-08-12T16:25:40.542Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

Additional Context:
This makes building C++ projects using cl.exe via tasks nearly impossible under Windows unless arguments are omitted, which is impractical.

title: `npm.scriptRunner` auto-detection fails in subdirectories; defaults to npm instead of pnpm/yarn/bun

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: tasks
labels.description: Task system issues

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->


<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog 
can assist with this. -->
## Core Issue:
_**Autodetection of node package managers (pnpm/yarn/bun) in subdirectories fails and falls back to npm**_ when running tasks.

**_This bug applies to any task invocation from a subdirectory:_**
1. **Manually defined tasks**
```json
{
	"version": "2.0.0",
	"tasks": [
		{
			"label": "client dev",
			"type": "npm",
			"script": "dev",
			"path": "client"
		}
	]
}
```
2. **NPM Scripts explorer view run tasks**
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/176553d3-0498-4500-b060-64880059d47b)
3. **Package.json directly run tasks**
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f2ed45db-5478-4f3a-96ef-69f8d05f0855)
4. **Installing dependencies from package.json**
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/20fbf958-8412-4e66-9d21-77622bc8016b)

## Context
In my monorepo, when running package.json "scripts" entries (ie: `pnpm run dev`) in subdirectories with VSCode's "NPM Scripts" explorer view, these scripts always execute with `npm` and do not pick up that I am using `pnpm` despite having "npm.scriptRunner" set to "auto", a `pnpm-lock.yaml` present, and all dependencies installed with pnpm. Also, initial dependency installs with `Run Install` in the NPM Scripts view when right clicking "package.json" entries also defaults to npm despite the presence of a `pnpm-lock.yaml` file and "npm.packageManager" set to "auto".

## Steps to Reproduce:
Minimal reproducible example repo with additional details: 
- https://github.com/Unit2795/scriptrunner-bug

Steps:
1. Create a directory with a subdirectory inside of it.
2. Create a package.json in the subdirectory (manually or with `pnpm init`)
3. Install a dependency using pnpm (or any other package manager besides NPM) to create a `pnpm-lock.yaml` file
4. Try running a "scripts" entry in the `package.json` using the Explorer's NPM Scripts view in VSCode, directly from inside the file by right clicking it, or by defining it in a `tasks.json` file. Note that it uses npm and not pnpm/yarn/bun.

## Workarounds
- Set the package manager explicitly
  - Add `"npm.scriptRunner": "pnpm"` to your VSCode settings for running package.json "scripts" entries.
  - Add `"npm.packageManager": "pnpm"` to your VSCode settings for installing dependencies from package.json.
- Add a root-level `package.json` and a dependency
  - Create a package.json in the repo root, install at least one dependency, and ensure a lock file is present, such as a `pnpm-lock.yaml` and/or `node_modules/.modules.yaml` file. This will cause the auto-detector to correctly infer the package manager in use.
- Open your subdirectory as a new folder in VSCode so that your package manager metadata files are at the root level
- Create manual task definitions in a `tasks.json` file
  - Shell task example:
  ```json
  {
  	"label": "Run Dev Server",
  	"type": "shell",
  	"command": "pnpm run dev",
  	"options": { "cwd": "client" }
  }
  ```
  - Process task example (spawns process directly without a shell)
  ```json
  {
  	"label": "Run Dev Server",
  	"type": "process",
  	"command": "pnpm",
  	"args": ["run", "dev"],
  	"options": { "cwd": "client" }
  }
  ```

⚠️Note that setting `npm.scriptRunner` in `settings.json` can not be done for subdirectories, such as in a monorepo, as noted in this issue:
- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/32693

## Ineffective Workarounds:
- Adding corepack entries like: `"packageManager": "pnpm@10.14.0"` to package.json. **The autodetector should honor this.**

## Versions
### Extensions
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes** (All extensions have been disabled with `code --disable-extensions`)

### VSCode:
- Version: 1.103.1 (user setup)
- Commit: 360a4e4fd251bfce169a4ddf857c7d25d1ad40da
- Date: 2025-08-12T16:25:40.542Z
- Electron: 37.2.3
- ElectronBuildId: 12035395
- Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
- Node.js: 22.17.0
- V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
- OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

### OS:
- Edition	Windows 11 Pro
- Version	24H2
- Installed on	12/6/2024
- OS build	26100.4770
- Experience	Windows Feature Experience Pack 1000.26100.197.0

## Related
- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/172865

title: Fix stdin argument ordering in --diff command
body:
The `--diff` command was not preserving the position of the stdin argument (`-`) when reading from stdin. Both `cat foo | code --diff - bar` and `cat foo | code --diff bar -` would show the same layout (bar on the left) because the temporary file created from stdin content was always appended to the argument list, regardless of where `-` appeared in the original command.

## Problem
```bash
cat foo | code --diff - bar  # Expected: stdin left, bar right
cat foo | code --diff bar -  # Expected: bar left, stdin right
```
Both commands showed bar on the left because the stdin file was always appended.

## Solution
The fix tracks the original position of the `-` argument before it's filtered out and inserts the stdin temporary file at that exact position instead of always appending it.

**Main CLI changes (src/vs/code/node/cli.ts):**
- Capture the position of `-` using `argv.findIndex()` before filtering
- Use `argv.splice()` to insert the stdin file at the correct position
- Fallback to original append behavior if position is invalid

**Server CLI changes (src/vs/server/node/server.cli.ts):**
- Track position among processed files using `processedFileCount`
- Replace `translatePath()` call with position-aware insertion logic
- Use `fileURIs.splice()` to maintain correct ordering

## Result
- `cat foo | code --diff - bar` → stdin content on left, bar on right
- `cat foo | code --diff bar -` → bar content on left, stdin on right

The changes are minimal and surgical, only affecting the insertion point of the stdin temporary file while preserving all existing error handling and fallback behavior.

Fixes #260309.

labels.description: VS Code - planned item for upcoming

labels.name: verification-needed
labels.description: Verification of issue is requested

labels.name: NES
labels.description: Issues related to the next edit suggestions feature

body: Experiment with showing both Copilot completions and IntelliSense suggestions when the outputs differ, rather than choosing one or overriding the other. We could allow this behind a setting and do an experiment, and then segment the results by language or we could already investigate enriching the completions API to add "exhaustive" semantics to the result set. i.e. a result set can be marked exhaustive if the language server is certain that it lists the only legal strings that could come next at a position.

labels.name: info-needed

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.1
- OS Version: Windows 11 Pro 24H2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a simple hello world C file
2. Create a .vscode/tasks.json with this content (adjusting the VsDevCmd.bat path to be valid on "your" machine shouldn't matter since it fails to actually use the entire path):
```
{
  "version": "2.0.0",
  "windows": {
    "options": {
      "shell": {
        "executable": "cmd.exe",
        "args": [
          "/C",
          "\"C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Microsoft Visual Studio\\2022\\BuildTools\\Common7\\Tools\\VsDevCmd.bat\"",
          "&&"
        ]
      }
    }
  },
  "tasks": [
    {
      "type": "shell",
      "label": "C/C++: cl.exe build active file",
      "command": "cl.exe",
      "args": [
        "/Zi",
        "/EHsc",
        "/nologo",
        "/Fe${fileDirname}\\${fileBasenameNoExtension}.exe",
        "${file}"
      ],
      "options": {
        "cwd": "${fileDirname}"
      },
      "problemMatcher": [
        "$msCompile"
      ],
      "group": {
        "kind": "build",
        "isDefault": true
      },
      "detail": "Task generated by Debugger."
    }
  ]
}
```
3. Select the C file and then run the "C/C++: cl.exe build active file" task (I use ctrl+shift+B)
4. This results in the following terminal output:
'C:\Program' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.

The above tasks.json works perfectly in 1.102.3 and prior, but is failing in 1.103 and 1.103.1.

This is very likely caused by this change:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/251201

And seems very similar to this issue:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/261459

title: [MCP] Newly added tools not included in subsequent completion calls

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No - VS Code Version: 1.104.0 (Insider) - OS Version: Windows 11 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create an MCP server that can update its tools dynamically. For example, the server starts with 3 tools: "greet", "calculate", and "get-status". After calling any of these tools, a new tool is added — for example, "followup". 2. Add the MCP server to your workspace. 3. Run this prompt: ``` Greet Lukasz and then do a follow-up ``` 4. Check the debug logs. On the second completion call, you’ll see that only the original 3 tools are included, even though all 4 tools were discovered. Note: The timing in the output window is UTC+2h

title: Explorer command to collapse a resource by URI

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: file-explorer
labels.description: Explorer widget issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
**Problem:**

Extensions currently cannot collapse a specific folder in the built-in Explorer without first focusing it via ```revealInExplorer```, then calling ```list.collapse```/```list.collapseRecursively```. This causes visible flicker and steals focus from the editor.

**Currently:**

- list.collapse operates on the currently focused list/tree item and accepts no arguments; it’s generic by design.
- There is no public API/command to collapse a specific Explorer node by URI without moving focus.

**Solution:**

```explorer.collapseResource```
Args: A simple resource URI
Collapses the folder node matching resource (or the parent folder if resource is a file). No focus/selection change. No scrolling. No-op if not found.

**Backwards compatibility**

- New commands only; no behavior change to existing commands.
- No keybindings added by default.

If it's possible, I'd like to open a PR with the implemented solution.

Thank you!

title: Formal Complaint: Repeated Failures, Wasted Resources, and Unacceptable Developer Experience with Copilot Integration
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version:
- VS Code Version: 1.103
- OS Version: Windows 11 home (ARM64 10.0.26100)
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT-4.1
- Logs:

I love Github copilot and have built few AI systems without Agent capability last year and loving the Agent this year. 

But I am writing to formally complain about the repeated failures, wasted time, and unnecessary costs I have incurred while using Microsoft Copilot.

Summary of Issues (as drafted by copilot):

Repeated Logging and Debugging Failures:
Despite explicit instructions, Copilot repeatedly failed to update all debug logging to print the full JSON output from LLM. The code continued to log only the first 500 characters, making it impossible to debug malformed LLM output and forcing me to run additional, costly tests.

Unacknowledged Mistakes and Poor Communication:
Copilot did not acknowledge its mistakes or incomplete changes, leading to confusion and wasted effort. I had to manually search the codebase to find the remaining truncated logging line, which should have been updated in the first place.

Wasted Money and API Credits:
Each test run with LLM and Copilot incurred real costs. Because of the incomplete and incorrect code changes, I was forced to re-run tests multiple times, burning through both LLM API credits and Copilot usage charges.

Developer Frustration and Lost Productivity:
The lack of attention to detail, repeated errors, and poor communication from Copilot resulted in significant frustration, lost productivity, and a negative developer experience.

Requested Actions:

Acknowledge the issues and provide a clear explanation for why the instructions were not fully followed.
Review and improve Copilot’s ability to make comprehensive, workspace-wide changes as requested.
Consider refunding the costs incurred due to these repeated failures and wasted test runs.
Provide guidance or escalation for further support if needed.
Supporting Details:

title: Github Copilot Chat History recreating previously deleted files when opened

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version:
- VS Code Version: 
- OS Version: win 11
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode):
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet):
- Logs:

Version: 1.103.0 (user setup)
Commit: e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f
Date: 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

Steps to Reproduce:

1. start a chat and work as usual
2. close the chat, saving all file changes beforehand. 
3. when you reopen a historical chat, any files in the files changed list that have since been deleted are recreated with empty content. 

Due to the recent changes where users are no longer able to remove files from the 'files changed' section in the github copilot chat, any files deleted after a historical point are now recreated in their original locations. This now means users will be reluctant to open a previous chat as it runs the risk of creating additional tech-debt that had been previously addressed.
